Marina Atsumi Oikawa

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/4902075240110625
  • Última atualização do currículo em 30/08/2018

Possui Pós-Doutorado(2016) pelo Instituto de Computação, Universidade Estadual de Campinas (Unicamp) e concluiu o Doutorado (2013) e Mestrado (2010) em Ciência da Computação pelo Nara Institute of Science and Technology (Japão), ambos revalidados pela Universidade Estadual de Campinas. Graduou-se em Bacharelado em Ciência da Computação pela Universidade Federal do Pará (2006) e em Licenciatura Plena em Matemática pela Universidade do Estado do Pará (2005). Principais áreas de pesquisa: Análise Forense de Documentos Digitais, Visão Computacional e Realidade Aumentada. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2014 - 2016
Multimedia Phylogeny Forest Reconstruction: Recovering the ancestry relationship of Images, Videos and Text Documents
Descrição: Nowadays, several cases of tampered digital media exist, depicting events that did not happen exactly the way they were reported, with some retouching, content inclusion or removal, among other types of operations. Whether these modifications were performed only for entertainment purposes or to forge digital evidence in crime investigations, it is undeniable the increasing importance of multimedia forensics research. In some cases, to simply investigate if one document is a duplicate of another is not enough; knowledge about the history of modifications is also important, since it can give us hints about its origi- nal creator and a better understanding of how the content was transformed along its lifetime. From this demand, a new research field called multimedia phylogeny has arisen, aiming at investigating how to infer the relationships among objects that belong to the same population. These relationships, represented by means of directed acyclic graphs, resemble the phylogenetic trees used in Biology and are a conve- nient way to describe the order and the chain of transformations used to create the digital object under investigation. In this research project, we aim at broadening the current state-of-the-art of multimedia phylogeny algorithms, by improving its robustness and expanding them from the image domain to videos and text documents. As a first step, we will target improvements on the calculation of the dissimilarity among the related objects, followed by new approaches for reconstructing phylogeny forests, that is, cases in which we have multiple objects with similar semantic content, but that might not be directly related to each other, being necessary to correctly place them in different processing trees. Furthermore, since most of the approaches developed so far are mainly applied to images, it is paramount to develop new methods to attend the particularities of videos and, in special, text documents, a type of media least explored and whose properties differ in many levels to images and videos. Other expected contributions of this research include the creation of new datasets and development of additional evaluation metrics when necessary..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Marina Atsumi Oikawa - Integrante / Anderson de Rezende Rocha - Coordenador / Zanoni Dias - Integrante / Siome Goldenstein - Integrante.
2009 - 2010
Physical presence simulation for video chatting communication
Descrição: Establishing a proper communication channel between two people geographically separated raises the issue of how to shorten the existent distance between them. A higher interaction level may be one decisive factor. Video chatting is considered one of the most popular remote communication solutions, which can be easily found in Instant Messaging (IM) protocols such as Yahoo Messenger, Google Chat, among others. Its affordable status attracts a large amount of people, allowing them to enjoy it with minimum settings. In a typical video chatting environment, two windows display video images from both, local and remote webcams, and the interaction is limited to hear and see the remote end. Nevertheless, physical barriers are still very much noticeable. For instance, it is impossible to hug or shake hands with your friend on the other side of the camera, even though you can listen and see him. This project proposes a one step forward in the interaction level of video chatting experience by creating a ?virtual portal? in both sides local space. That means simulate physical presence of one user into a second user?s real world. For example, it will be possible to stretch your arm towards the camera and seeing it coming out in the other user?s webcam as if you were reaching him. In summary, this project intended to provide to the user a closer sensation of presence by making use of computer vision based Augmented Reality techniques combined with real time video merging algorithms and as a final result, a more interactive communication channel..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Mestrado acadêmico: (3) Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Marina Atsumi Oikawa - Integrante / Jordi Carres Polo - Integrante / Igor de Souza Almeida - Integrante / Hirokazu Kato - Coordenador / Tatsuya Hiramatsu - Integrante.
2008 - 2008
Range finder using a camera-projector system.
Descrição: This project aimed the development of a range finder system to obtain a complete 3D model of the target object using a camera and a projector. By the end of the project, users were invited to construct clay models that were measured by our system and inserted in a virtual city. Then, they could see their own models in an augmented reality environment using a Head-Mounted Display and interact with them using a cup-shaped object..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Marina Atsumi Oikawa - Integrante / Yosuke Koide - Integrante / Hirokazu Kato - Coordenador / Tatsuya Hiramatsu - Integrante.
